values.description: Wrench doesn't affect static links, so they shouldn't subscribe to wrench messages. This should significantly reduce the number of advertised topics for worlds with lots of static models.
values.title: Static links don't subscribe to wrench messages

summary.raw: Wrench doesn't affect static links, so they shouldn't subscribe to wrench messages. This should significantly reduce the number of advertised topics for worlds with lots of static models.
summary.html: Wrench doesn't affect static links, so they shouldn't subscribe to wrench messages. This should significantly reduce the number of advertised topics for worlds with lots of static models.

values.description:
issue #1653 - The current behavior for creating heightmaps on the rendering side is to request height data from the physics server. However, currently protobuf msgs over certain size will be rejected and so heightmaps fail to load on the rendering side.

This PR updates the heightmap loading process on the rendering side to first try load the height data locally if available, if not, request the data from the server. 

Note, if the heightmap data is not present on the locally (e.g. running gzclient on a different machine that doesn't have the heightmap img), then the user will still run into the same problem. Future solution is to explore dividing large heightmap data into chunks and sending them to the rendering side using multiple msgs.

jenkins:

- [nvidia gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/636/) - no related test failures

- [abi](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/85/API_ABI_report/) - ok
values.title: Load heightmap data locally in rendering

This PR updates the heightmap loading process on the rendering side to first try load the height data locally if available, if not, request the data from the server. 

Note, if the heightmap data is not present on the locally (e.g. running gzclient on a different machine that doesn't have the heightmap img), then the user will still run into the same problem. Future solution is to explore dividing large heightmap data into chunks and sending them to the rendering side using multiple msgs.

summary.html:
issue #1653 - The current behavior for creating heightmaps on the rendering side is to request height data from the physics server. However, currently protobuf msgs over certain size will be rejected and so heightmaps fail to load on the rendering side.

This PR updates the heightmap loading process on the rendering side to first try load the height data locally if available, if not, request the data from the server.

Note, if the heightmap data is not present on the locally (e.g. running gzclient on a different machine that doesn't have the heightmap img), then the user will still run into the same problem. Future solution is to explore dividing large heightmap data into chunks and sending them to the rendering side using multiple msgs.

jenkins:

  • nvidia gpu - no related test failures

  • abi - ok

values.description:
added [tinyobjloader](https://github.com/syoyo/tinyobjloader) in `deps` dir that does the bulk of the work for parsing and loading the obj mesh and material (.mtl) files

The `OBJLoader` class takes the data from `tinyobjloader` and constructs the gazebo mesh and material objects. Nothing fancy like reusing vertex/normal/uv data is done in this version.  

Here's an [example gazebo cordless drill model](https://www.dropbox.com/s/pmi8nc2joewccsf/cordless_drill_obj.zip?dl=0) that uses a .obj mesh

jenkins:

- [nvidia-gpu](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/640/) - ok

- not sure why the [abi checker](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/90/) is not working
values.title: Add support for loading wavefront obj mesh files

values.description:
Similar to this [ign-transport pull request](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/176/add-syntax-proto2-to-proto-files-to/diff).

Prevents these console warnings with protobuf3: 

~~~
[libprotobuf WARNING google/protobuf/compiler/parser.cc:547]
 No syntax specified for the proto file: int.proto.
 Please use 'syntax = "proto2";' or 'syntax = "proto3";' to specify a syntax version.
 (Defaulted to proto2 syntax.)
[libprotobuf WARNING google/protobuf/compiler/parser.cc:547]
 No syntax specified for the proto file: vector3d.proto.
 Please use 'syntax = "proto2";' or 'syntax = "proto3";' to specify a syntax version.
 (Defaulted to proto2 syntax.)
~~~
values.title: Add syntax = proto2 in proto files to fix some protobuf3 warnings

values.description:
A big chunk of gzclient's loading time is spent generating visualizations. With this pull request, visualizations are generated on demand instead, so the generation burden is not concentrated on startup. This is especially important when loading big worlds with thousands of links.

This also addressed a TODO for moving the collision visual generation to the client.

And it also fixed this problem:

1. On the top menu, choose "View" something

1. Visualization is turned on for all existing models

1. Insert a new model and the visualization is not there.
values.title: Generate visualizations on demand

summary.raw:
A big chunk of gzclient's loading time is spent generating visualizations. With this pull request, visualizations are generated on demand instead, so the generation burden is not concentrated on startup. This is especially important when loading big worlds with thousands of links.

This also addressed a TODO for moving the collision visual generation to the client.

And it also fixed this problem:

1. On the top menu, choose "View" something

1. Visualization is turned on for all existing models

1. Insert a new model and the visualization is not there.
summary.html:
A big chunk of gzclient's loading time is spent generating visualizations. With this pull request, visualizations are generated on demand instead, so the generation burden is not concentrated on startup. This is especially important when loading big worlds with thousands of links.

This also addressed a TODO for moving the collision visual generation to the client.

And it also fixed this problem:

  1. On the top menu, choose "View" something

  2. Visualization is turned on for all existing models

  3. Insert a new model and the visualization is not there.

values.description:
This is a resurrection of pull request #1825 from @jlee02, that adds support for dart5 to gazebo8. This is an intermediate step towards supporting dart6, which has already been released. I figured that splitting it into two pull requests would make the review easier.

There are a few tests that are disabled due to known issues (not supporting ray sensor or pr2's closed kinematic loops) and one new test failure of the sonar sensor (#2062). On the bright side, some improvements were made to rigid body rotations, so that a portion of the physics_link test can pass without relaxed tolerances.

A jenkins job has been queued:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any_dart4-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia_docker/28
values.title: Support Dart5 in gazebo8

On the bright side, some improvements were made to rigid body rotations, so that a portion of the physics_link test can pass without relaxed tolerances.

values.description:
We have noticed in jenkins that `UNIT_gz_TEST` is pretty flaky. It is the most common failure on our homebrew builds, which repeat failing tests once to try to week out flakes. The gazebo7 homebrew build has been failing most often during the [gzTest.Model subtest](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64/85/testReport/(root)/gzTest/Model/), but it can also timeout or crash, in which case the [UNIT_gz_TEST.test_ran](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci_BTCoverage-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/135/testReport/(root)/UNIT_gz_TEST/test_ran/) failure can be seen.

This PR reduces the flakiness of the test and disables some troublesome expectations:

1. Improve initialization by calling `gazebo::client::setup()` instead of `gazebo::transport::init()` and then later `gazebo::transport::run()`. This is the preferred way to write listener programs now. This required linking the test to the `libgazebo_client` library.

2. Wait for the `~/world_stats` topic to be listed. The `gzTest.Topic` test can fail if the `gzserver` has not finished initializing, so the `transport::getAdvertisedTopics` API is used to wait for that topic. This is helpful for the other tests as well to wait for the gzserver to be ready before proceeding.

3. Don't start a `gzserver` with the `init()` and `fini()` calls for the SDF test, since it doesn't need it.

4. When deleting a model, the test currently expects to see an `entity_delete` message on the `~/request` topic with some of the text in the message matching the name of the model to be deleted. This is problematic, however, since `Link::Fini` [publishes entity_delete requests with an integer id of its child visuals](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/31944e8d9da6220d0c90a2fc30b0c1d8c75751b6/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Link.cc-272), and these messages don't contain the model name, just an integer. There is a [design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/31/insertion-and-deletion-flow/diff) about improving model insertion and deletion, so I would like to disable these expectations until that design document is implemented. At that time, it should be easier to write reasonable expectations.

5. Finally, I observed a problem that `~/factory` messages were being published, and we were later able to get `model_info` about the created model, but the `~/factory` messages were never received by the test, leading to failed expectations. I documented this in #2069 and disabled the expectations.

The test should be more reliable now. I have tested it repeatedly on trusty and homebrew and it is passing reliably now. It passed in one [homebrew jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/693/testReport/(root)/gzTest/) too.
values.title: Reduce flakiness of UNIT_gz_TEST

summary.raw:
We have noticed in jenkins that `UNIT_gz_TEST` is pretty flaky. It is the most common failure on our homebrew builds, which repeat failing tests once to try to week out flakes. The gazebo7 homebrew build has been failing most often during the [gzTest.Model subtest](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo7-homebrew-amd64/85/testReport/(root)/gzTest/Model/), but it can also timeout or crash, in which case the [UNIT_gz_TEST.test_ran](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci_BTCoverage-default-trusty-amd64-gpu-none/135/testReport/(root)/UNIT_gz_TEST/test_ran/) failure can be seen.

This PR reduces the flakiness of the test and disables some troublesome expectations:

1. Improve initialization by calling `gazebo::client::setup()` instead of `gazebo::transport::init()` and then later `gazebo::transport::run()`. This is the preferred way to write listener programs now. This required linking the test to the `libgazebo_client` library.

2. Wait for the `~/world_stats` topic to be listed. The `gzTest.Topic` test can fail if the `gzserver` has not finished initializing, so the `transport::getAdvertisedTopics` API is used to wait for that topic. This is helpful for the other tests as well to wait for the gzserver to be ready before proceeding.

3. Don't start a `gzserver` with the `init()` and `fini()` calls for the SDF test, since it doesn't need it.

4. When deleting a model, the test currently expects to see an `entity_delete` message on the `~/request` topic with some of the text in the message matching the name of the model to be deleted. This is problematic, however, since `Link::Fini` [publishes entity_delete requests with an integer id of its child visuals](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/31944e8d9da6220d0c90a2fc30b0c1d8c75751b6/gazebo/physics/Link.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Link.cc-272), and these messages don't contain the model name, just an integer. There is a [design document](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/pull-requests/31/insertion-and-deletion-flow/diff) about improving model insertion and deletion, so I would like to disable these expectations until that design document is implemented. At that time, it should be easier to write reasonable expectations.

5. Finally, I observed a problem that `~/factory` messages were being published, and we were later able to get `model_info` about the created model, but the `~/factory` messages were never received by the test, leading to failed expectations. I documented this in #2069 and disabled the expectations.

The test should be more reliable now. I have tested it repeatedly on trusty and homebrew and it is passing reliably now. It passed in one [homebrew jenkins build](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/693/testReport/(root)/gzTest/) too.
summary.html:
We have noticed in jenkins that UNIT_gz_TEST is pretty flaky. It is the most common failure on our homebrew builds, which repeat failing tests once to try to week out flakes. The gazebo7 homebrew build has been failing most often during the gzTest.Model subtest, but it can also timeout or crash, in which case the UNIT_gz_TEST.test_ran failure can be seen.

This PR reduces the flakiness of the test and disables some troublesome expectations:

  1. Improve initialization by calling gazebo::client::setup() instead of gazebo::transport::init() and then later gazebo::transport::run(). This is the preferred way to write listener programs now. This required linking the test to the libgazebo_client library.

  2. Wait for the ~/world_stats topic to be listed. The gzTest.Topic test can fail if the gzserver has not finished initializing, so the transport::getAdvertisedTopics API is used to wait for that topic. This is helpful for the other tests as well to wait for the gzserver to be ready before proceeding.

  3. Don't start a gzserver with the init() and fini() calls for the SDF test, since it doesn't need it.

  4. When deleting a model, the test currently expects to see an entity_delete message on the ~/request topic with some of the text in the message matching the name of the model to be deleted. This is problematic, however, since Link::Fini publishes entity_delete requests with an integer id of its child visuals, and these messages don't contain the model name, just an integer. There is a design document about improving model insertion and deletion, so I would like to disable these expectations until that design document is implemented. At that time, it should be easier to write reasonable expectations.

  5. Finally, I observed a problem that ~/factory messages were being published, and we were later able to get model_info about the created model, but the ~/factory messages were never received by the test, leading to failed expectations. I documented this in #2069 and disabled the expectations.

The test should be more reliable now. I have tested it repeatedly on trusty and homebrew and it is passing reliably now. It passed in one homebrew jenkins build too.

values.description:
These are more changes that are tangential to the physics pimpl-ization effort.

This pull request contains mostly `ignition::math` updates to render.

The `explicit` keyword has been added to a number of constructors. This fixes some style errors on xenial. It is also a good practice to prevent automatic copying.
values.title: Pimpl physics3

summary.raw:
These are more changes that are tangential to the physics pimpl-ization effort.

This pull request contains mostly `ignition::math` updates to render.

The `explicit` keyword has been added to a number of constructors. This fixes some style errors on xenial. It is also a good practice to prevent automatic copying.
summary.html:
These are more changes that are tangential to the physics pimpl-ization effort.

This pull request contains mostly ignition::math updates to render.

The explicit keyword has been added to a number of constructors. This fixes some style errors on xenial. It is also a good practice to prevent automatic copying.

values.description:
you should now be able to specify your own material script for heightmaps in sdf, see [test/worlds/heightmap_material.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/new#chg-test/worlds/heightmap_material.world) for example. 

The material script replaces the default heightmap shaders in gazebo. The downside is that there won't be shadows on the heightmap anymore and it's up to the user to generate their own shadows in their shaders.
values.title: Support custom material scripts for heightmaps

summary.raw:
you should now be able to specify your own material script for heightmaps in sdf, see [test/worlds/heightmap_material.world](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/new#chg-test/worlds/heightmap_material.world) for example. 

The material script replaces the default heightmap shaders in gazebo. The downside is that there won't be shadows on the heightmap anymore and it's up to the user to generate their own shadows in their shaders.
summary.html:
you should now be able to specify your own material script for heightmaps in sdf, see test/worlds/heightmap_material.world for example.

The material script replaces the default heightmap shaders in gazebo. The downside is that there won't be shadows on the heightmap anymore and it's up to the user to generate their own shadows in their shaders.

values.description:
Currently we include qt header files to determine info about OSX, but this isn't necessary. We used to do it to determine if carbon or cocoa was in use, but carbon is old, so just use cocoa for now. Then switch all `Q_OS_MAC` macros to `__APPLE__`.

This should work with qt4 or qt5, but it was causing problems with qt5 since the `Q_OS_MAC` symbol was renamed to `Q_OS_OSX`. It's easier just to remove it entirely.

Thanks to @iche033 for helping figure this out.
values.title: Prepare for qt5 on osx

summary.raw:
Currently we include qt header files to determine info about OSX, but this isn't necessary. We used to do it to determine if carbon or cocoa was in use, but carbon is old, so just use cocoa for now. Then switch all `Q_OS_MAC` macros to `__APPLE__`.

This should work with qt4 or qt5, but it was causing problems with qt5 since the `Q_OS_MAC` symbol was renamed to `Q_OS_OSX`. It's easier just to remove it entirely.

Thanks to @iche033 for helping figure this out.
summary.html:
Currently we include qt header files to determine info about OSX, but this isn't necessary. We used to do it to determine if carbon or cocoa was in use, but carbon is old, so just use cocoa for now. Then switch all Q_OS_MAC macros to __APPLE__.

This should work with qt4 or qt5, but it was causing problems with qt5 since the Q_OS_MAC symbol was renamed to Q_OS_OSX. It's easier just to remove it entirely.

Thanks to @iche033 for helping figure this out.

values.description:
Fix for issue #1560.

This changes the `GLWidget` repaint/update loop to use `UserCamera::RenderRate`. You should notice a significant drop in CPU usage with this pull request.

values.description:
A few heightmap fixes in this PR:

* Fix loading DEM size in rendering when the `<size>` is not specified. It should now use the size info in the DEM file

* Enable loading DEMs with negative elevations / heights

* Fix ODE heightmap bounding box limits (models were not colliding with DEM heightmaps with certain min/max elevations)

* Fix DEM height z scale calculation. 

* Removed `try/catch` block in `Scene` when creating a heightmap - it was masking a couple of OGRE exceptions which should now be fixed.

I added some TODOs in the code as a reminder to address them later after merging forward to gazebo8 so we don't break ABI.

jenkins:

[gpu-nividia](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/676/) - ok 

[abi](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-xenial-amd64/112/API_ABI_report/) - ok
values.title: Fix DEM heightmap size, collision, scale

summary.raw:
A few heightmap fixes in this PR:

* Fix loading DEM size in rendering when the `<size>` is not specified. It should now use the size info in the DEM file

* Enable loading DEMs with negative elevations / heights

* Fix ODE heightmap bounding box limits (models were not colliding with DEM heightmaps with certain min/max elevations)

* Fix DEM height z scale calculation. 

* Removed `try/catch` block in `Scene` when creating a heightmap - it was masking a couple of OGRE exceptions which should now be fixed.

I added some TODOs in the code as a reminder to address them later after merging forward to gazebo8 so we don't break ABI.

summary.html:
A few heightmap fixes in this PR:

  • Fix loading DEM size in rendering when the <size> is not specified. It should now use the size info in the DEM file

  • Enable loading DEMs with negative elevations / heights

  • Fix ODE heightmap bounding box limits (models were not colliding with DEM heightmaps with certain min/max elevations)

  • Fix DEM height z scale calculation.

  • Removed try/catch block in Scene when creating a heightmap - it was masking a couple of OGRE exceptions which should now be fixed.

I added some TODOs in the code as a reminder to address them later after merging forward to gazebo8 so we don't break ABI.

jenkins:

gpu-nividia - ok

abi - ok

values.description:
E.g. when an SDF file contains <uri>scheme://rest.of.address</uri>, there is a possibility to add a resolver that can resolve "scheme://" URIs to filesystem paths.

This is needed to get a more proper interpretation of ROS' "package://" schemes.

Now it is just a proposal. It probably breaks ABI. So I'm not sure if branching off gazebo7 is the right way. Or should I branch off default?
values.title: Added the possibility to specify additional URI resolvers based on URI scheme.

summary.raw:
E.g. when an SDF file contains <uri>scheme://rest.of.address</uri>, there is a possibility to add a resolver that can resolve "scheme://" URIs to filesystem paths.

This is needed to get a more proper interpretation of ROS' "package://" schemes.

Now it is just a proposal. It probably breaks ABI. So I'm not sure if branching off gazebo7 is the right way. Or should I branch off default?
summary.html:
E.g. when an SDF file contains <uri>scheme://rest.of.address</uri>, there is a possibility to add a resolver that can resolve "scheme://" URIs to filesystem paths.

This is needed to get a more proper interpretation of ROS' "package://" schemes.

Now it is just a proposal. It probably breaks ABI. So I'm not sure if branching off gazebo7 is the right way. Or should I branch off default?

values.description:
* Fix triangle inequality expectation in msgs test to `>=` instead of `>`

* Use SetFromBox in msgs::AddBoxLink and model editor to reduce duplicate inertia calculations

* Use SetFromSphere helper function

* Use SetFromCylinderZ in msgs and model editor

* Use msgs::Set(Inertial, MassMatrix) in Add*Link functions

* Add copy constructor, Ign(), and operator= for physics::Inertial to convert to ignition::math::Inertiald
values.title: Use ignition inertia helpers

summary.raw:
* Fix triangle inequality expectation in msgs test to `>=` instead of `>`

* Use SetFromBox in msgs::AddBoxLink and model editor to reduce duplicate inertia calculations

* Use SetFromSphere helper function

* Use SetFromCylinderZ in msgs and model editor

* Use msgs::Set(Inertial, MassMatrix) in Add*Link functions

* Add copy constructor, Ign(), and operator= for physics::Inertial to convert to ignition::math::Inertiald
summary.html:
• Fix triangle inequality expectation in msgs test to >= instead of >

  • Use SetFromBox in msgs::AddBoxLink and model editor to reduce duplicate inertia calculations

  • Use SetFromSphere helper function

  • Use SetFromCylinderZ in msgs and model editor

  • Use msgs::Set(Inertial, MassMatrix) in Add*Link functions

  • Add copy constructor, Ign(), and operator= for physics::Inertial to convert to ignition::math::Inertiald

values.reason: back to doing a design document

values.description:
* ~~~changed subsampling level to 1 (no interpolation between vertices). This was set to 2 in pull request #493 probably for the terrain editor. At a value=2, we ended up with 4x the number of triangles in  the heightmap mesh~~~

* added option to enable level of details (LOD). This is mainly for the client side as we don't want LOD to change on server side which will cause mismatch between heightmap visual and collision.

 To see LOD in effect, add this option to the `gui.ini` file:

~~~
[heightmap]
lod=3
~~~

[Here](https://www.dropbox.com/s/0b6uqlr6s3yjvv7/red_dem.zip?dl=0)'s a zip file of a large dem model to test with. Switch to wireframe mode and slowly rotate the camera to look at the terrain from a top down view to a 45 degree angle. The heightmap mesh should become coarser as the camera angle gets perpendicular to the heightmap normal.
values.title: Improve heightmap rendering performance: LOD

summary.raw:
* ~~~changed subsampling level to 1 (no interpolation between vertices). This was set to 2 in pull request #493 probably for the terrain editor. At a value=2, we ended up with 4x the number of triangles in  the heightmap mesh~~~

* added option to enable level of details (LOD). This is mainly for the client side as we don't want LOD to change on server side which will cause mismatch between heightmap visual and collision.

 To see LOD in effect, add this option to the `gui.ini` file:

~~~
[heightmap]
lod=3
~~~

[Here](https://www.dropbox.com/s/0b6uqlr6s3yjvv7/red_dem.zip?dl=0)'s a zip file of a large dem model to test with. Switch to wireframe mode and slowly rotate the camera to look at the terrain from a top down view to a 45 degree angle. The heightmap mesh should become coarser as the camera angle gets perpendicular to the heightmap normal.
summary.html:
• ~changed subsampling level to 1 (no interpolation between vertices). This was set to 2 in pull request #493 probably for the terrain editor. At a value=2, we ended up with 4x the number of triangles in the heightmap mesh~

  • added option to enable level of details (LOD). This is mainly for the client side as we don't want LOD to change on server side which will cause mismatch between heightmap visual and collision.

To see LOD in effect, add this option to the gui.ini file:

[heightmap]
lod=3

Here's a zip file of a large dem model to test with. Switch to wireframe mode and slowly rotate the camera to look at the terrain from a top down view to a 45 degree angle. The heightmap mesh should become coarser as the camera angle gets perpendicular to the heightmap normal.

values.reason: observed unusual ogre terrain lod behavior with certain heightmap sizes. Need to investigate further.

values.description:
Given the heavy load of tests in the compilation it might be convenient to disable them by default and have to enable them explicitly.

Be sure that we merge the [corresponding pull request in release-tools](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/319/enable-test-suite-compilation-explicitly/diff) before so we don't end up without tests.
values.title: Disable tests compilation by default in cmake

values.description:
This model plugin consumes messages published by `KeyboardGUIPlugin` to control joints in a model. Hopefully the documentation in the header is sufficient to make the usage clear.

Added two worlds using the plugin:

* `worlds/simple_arm_teleop.world`: This is intended as a demo, it uses all 3 kinds of teleop with badly tuned PID

* `test/worlds/keys_to_joints.world`: A few simpler models for testing purposes
values.title: Keys to joints plugin

Added two worlds using the plugin:

  • test/worlds/keys_to_joints.world: A few simpler models for testing purposes

values.description:
The extent of `math::Box` created in each collision's `GetBoundingBox()` is never set to `EXTENT_FINITE`. That makes the box from each new collision in the link to be overwritten, resulting in the bounding box of the complete model being generated as the bounding box of the last link in the model definition.

The final generated bounding box would either match the bounding box of the last collision in the last link, or infinite box if the collision does not exist in the last link of the model.
values.title: Fix #2089: Incorrect model visual and collision bounding box

summary.raw:
The extent of `math::Box` created in each collision's `GetBoundingBox()` is never set to `EXTENT_FINITE`. That makes the box from each new collision in the link to be overwritten, resulting in the bounding box of the complete model being generated as the bounding box of the last link in the model definition.

The final generated bounding box would either match the bounding box of the last collision in the last link, or infinite box if the collision does not exist in the last link of the model.
summary.html:
The extent of math::Box created in each collision's GetBoundingBox() is never set to EXTENT_FINITE. That makes the box from each new collision in the link to be overwritten, resulting in the bounding box of the complete model being generated as the bounding box of the last link in the model definition.

The final generated bounding box would either match the bounding box of the last collision in the last link, or infinite box if the collision does not exist in the last link of the model.

values.description:
* Added the possibility to specify additional URI resolvers based on URI scheme.

Retargeting #2479 to default. Compilation, code check and tests ok on my machine.

I also made use of the newly introduced URI class. For that, I needed to add ability to recognize absolute URIs to this class (I did it in ABI compatible way, no API changes, no test cases broken, two more added).
values.title: Add uri resolvers default

I also made use of the newly introduced URI class. For that, I needed to add ability to recognize absolute URIs to this class (I did it in ABI compatible way, no API changes, no test cases broken, two more added).
summary.html:
• Added the possibility to specify additional URI resolvers based on URI scheme.

Retargeting #2479 to default. Compilation, code check and tests ok on my machine.

I also made use of the newly introduced URI class. For that, I needed to add ability to recognize absolute URIs to this class (I did it in ABI compatible way, no API changes, no test cases broken, two more added).

- added checking for null variables

values.description:
There is a race condition in `ContactSensor::Fini`. The call to get parent link, `world->GetEntity`, may return a null pointer as the link may have already been removed in the physics thread.

Added an integration test - the test fails on my machine without this patch. 

[jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/732/) - ok
values.title: Fix contact sensor cleanup

summary.raw:
There is a race condition in `ContactSensor::Fini`. The call to get parent link, `world->GetEntity`, may return a null pointer as the link may have already been removed in the physics thread.

Added an integration test - the test fails on my machine without this patch. 

[jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/732/) - ok
summary.html:
There is a race condition in ContactSensor::Fini. The call to get parent link, world->GetEntity, may return a null pointer as the link may have already been removed in the physics thread.

Added an integration test - the test fails on my machine without this patch.

jenkins - ok

values.description:
part of the work done on integrating ogre 1.9 in gazebo on OS X

the `#version 120` string at the beginning of the ogre rtshaderlib glsl shader files needs to be removed as ogre 1.9+ will auto prepend this string at runtime. 

See [this commit](https://bitbucket.org/sinbad/ogre/commits/400b04ec611c/) for similar changes done in the ogre repo. We still support ogre versions < 1.9 so I decided to use cmake for removing the version string. I'm open to other approaches.

This is needed to make shadows work on OSX with ogre 1.9.
values.title: Remove ogre rtshaderlib glsl version string for ogre 1.9 on OSX

summary.raw:
part of the work done on integrating ogre 1.9 in gazebo on OS X

the `#version 120` string at the beginning of the ogre rtshaderlib glsl shader files needs to be removed as ogre 1.9+ will auto prepend this string at runtime. 

See [this commit](https://bitbucket.org/sinbad/ogre/commits/400b04ec611c/) for similar changes done in the ogre repo. We still support ogre versions < 1.9 so I decided to use cmake for removing the version string. I'm open to other approaches.

This is needed to make shadows work on OSX with ogre 1.9.
summary.html:
part of the work done on integrating ogre 1.9 in gazebo on OS X

the #version 120 string at the beginning of the ogre rtshaderlib glsl shader files needs to be removed as ogre 1.9+ will auto prepend this string at runtime.

See this commit for similar changes done in the ogre repo. We still support ogre versions < 1.9 so I decided to use cmake for removing the version string. I'm open to other approaches.

This is needed to make shadows work on OSX with ogre 1.9.

values.description:
[Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/735/) is :large_blue_circle: 

I noticed that there were a lot of gazebo/math includes in common which weren't being used, so this removes them.

In fact, gazebo/math could be completely removed from common if it weren't for a couple of functions which were deprecated, but we forgot to place deprecation warnings for them. So I added the warnings, but for 8.0 instead of 7.0.
values.title: Remove unused gazebo::math includes from common

values.description:
This adds visualization markers to gazebo. The interface to markers is through ignition transport. Included in this pull request is a new example stand-alone executable, and `gz marker` command line tool.

The [ignition::msgs::Marker](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/07607e5f1e77eceec0273f6c73cee5aaa5768fe4/ignition/msgs/marker.proto?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) message type is used to create, modify, and destroy markers.

For command line usage help: `gz marker -h`
values.title: Markers

summary.raw:
This adds visualization markers to gazebo. The interface to markers is through ignition transport. Included in this pull request is a new example stand-alone executable, and `gz marker` command line tool.

The [ignition::msgs::Marker](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/src/07607e5f1e77eceec0273f6c73cee5aaa5768fe4/ignition/msgs/marker.proto?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default) message type is used to create, modify, and destroy markers.

For command line usage help: `gz marker -h`
summary.html:
This adds visualization markers to gazebo. The interface to markers is through ignition transport. Included in this pull request is a new example stand-alone executable, and gz marker command line tool.

The ignition::msgs::Marker message type is used to create, modify, and destroy markers.

For command line usage help: gz marker -h

values.description:
The idea comes from @jlee02 explained in [a different pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2489/disable-tests-compilation-by-default-in/diff#comment-26266415). I'm point this change to default instead of gazebo7, seems pretty intrusive for me to include in a minor bump.

Remove the cmake `ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION` parameter and exclude all tests compilation from `make all` so a simple `make` call won't compile any single test file. 

The whole test suite can be compiled by running `make tests`. All the individual tests make targets are generated when calling `cmake` so they are available in the form of `make <binary_test_name>` (i.e `make UNIT_gz_TEST`).

Note that this PR should go in sync with [the corresponding release-tools PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/325/adapt-gazebo-build-to-new-make-tests/diff) and [fixes to our install from source tutorial](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/382/remove-enable_tests_compilation-from/diff).

Testing runs:

  * [Ubuntu Linux](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/720/)
  * [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/746/)
values.title: Disable tests compilation by default. New 'make tests' target.

summary.raw:
The idea comes from @jlee02 explained in [a different pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2489/disable-tests-compilation-by-default-in/diff#comment-26266415). I'm point this change to default instead of gazebo7, seems pretty intrusive for me to include in a minor bump.

Remove the cmake `ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION` parameter and exclude all tests compilation from `make all` so a simple `make` call won't compile any single test file. 

The whole test suite can be compiled by running `make tests`. All the individual tests make targets are generated when calling `cmake` so they are available in the form of `make <binary_test_name>` (i.e `make UNIT_gz_TEST`).

Note that this PR should go in sync with [the corresponding release-tools PR](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/325/adapt-gazebo-build-to-new-make-tests/diff) and [fixes to our install from source tutorial](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-requests/382/remove-enable_tests_compilation-from/diff).

Testing runs:

  * [Ubuntu Linux](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/720/)
  * [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/All/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/746/)
summary.html:
The idea comes from @jlee02 explained in a different pull request. I'm point this change to default instead of gazebo7, seems pretty intrusive for me to include in a minor bump.

Remove the cmake ENABLE_TESTS_COMPILATION parameter and exclude all tests compilation from make all so a simple make call won't compile any single test file.

The whole test suite can be compiled by running make tests. All the individual tests make targets are generated when calling cmake so they are available in the form of make <binary_test_name> (i.e make UNIT_gz_TEST).

Note that this PR should go in sync with the corresponding release-tools PR and fixes to our install from source tutorial.

Testing runs:

  • Ubuntu Linux
  • Homebrew

issue #2097

PR based on the patch from @mallanmba.

I added an integration test that passes on ubuntu but disabled it on OSX as I realized that wide angle camera doesn't work there due to the version of the shaders. Downgrading the version should fix it. I'll address that separately.

Note there is a typo in the branch name..

jenkins:

nvidia-gpu - ok. warning fixed in daf5cac

homebrew - ok

values.description:
When a model is removed, some topics remain in the topics viewer and do not get removed. 

Calling `publisher.reset()` does not destroy the publisher object as a shared pointer is also stored inside a vector in `transport::Node`. We need to call `Fini` explicitly to unadvertise the topic.

jenkins:

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/751/) - ok. 1 style warning fixed in e6349b1
values.title: Clean up advertised topics list after model removal

summary.raw:
When a model is removed, some topics remain in the topics viewer and do not get removed. 

Calling `publisher.reset()` does not destroy the publisher object as a shared pointer is also stored inside a vector in `transport::Node`. We need to call `Fini` explicitly to unadvertise the topic.

jenkins:

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/751/) - ok. 1 style warning fixed in e6349b1
summary.html:
When a model is removed, some topics remain in the topics viewer and do not get removed.

Calling publisher.reset() does not destroy the publisher object as a shared pointer is also stored inside a vector in transport::Node. We need to call Fini explicitly to unadvertise the topic.

jenkins:

homebrew - ok. 1 style warning fixed in e6349b1
